verses.text: Then the Israelites set out and camped in the plains of Moab, across the Jordan from Jericho.
verses.comment: The mention of camping in Moab foreshadows significant events involving Israel's faithfulness and external threats. Jericho is a key location for entry into the promised land.

verses.text: Balak son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.
verses.comment: Balak's fear is rooted in Israel's victory over the Amorites. This sets the stage for his attempt to seek supernatural help against Israel.

verses.text: Moab was very afraid of the people, because they were so numerous. Moab was gripped with dread because of the Israelites.
verses.comment: Israel's growing numbers inspire fear in Moab, showing the fulfillment of God's promise to multiply His people (Genesis 15:5).

verses.text: Moab said to the elders of Midian, 'This horde will eat up everything around us, like an ox eats up the grass in the field.' So Balak son of Zippor, who was king of Moab at that time,
verses.comment: Moab and Midian join forces fearing devastation by Israel. Midian later becomes significant in the spiritual corruption of Israel (Numbers 25).

verses.text: sent messengers to summon Balaam son of Beor, who was in Pethor, near the River, in the land of his people. They said, 'A people has come out of Egypt; they cover the face of the land, and are settling opposite me.'
verses.comment: Balaam is called as a diviner from far off, highlighting the perceived spiritual power against God's chosen people. Note the repetition that Israel came out of Egypt—key in salvation history.

verses.text: 'Come now, curse these people for me, since they are too strong for me. Perhaps I can defeat them and drive them out of the land. For I know that whoever you bless is blessed, and whoever you curse is cursed.'
verses.comment: Balak seeks Balaam to counteract Israel's blessing. God's promise to Abraham is echoed: God's people cannot be cursed, and those who bless them are blessed.

verses.text: So the elders of Moab and Midian departed, taking with them the fee for divination. They came to Balaam and told him what Balak had said.
verses.comment: The 'fee for divination' indicates the widespread practice of consulting spiritual powers for guidance, though the biblical perspective is critical of such practices.

verses.text: Balaam said to them, 'Stay here overnight, and I will bring back to you whatever answer the LORD gives me.' So the officials of Moab stayed with Balaam.
verses.comment: Balaam waits on the LORD for guidance, showing God is able to use even non-Israelite prophets to accomplish His purposes.

verses.text: God came to Balaam and said, 'Who are these men with you?'
verses.comment: God initiates the encounter, showing His sovereignty even over pagan diviners. This prefigures God speaking through unexpected vessels.

verses.text: Balaam said to God, 'Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, sent me this message:'
verses.comment: Balaam's openness to God is notable despite his pagan background. It reveals God's reach extends beyond the boundaries of Israel.

verses.text: 'A people has come out of Egypt; they cover the land. Now, come and curse them for me. Perhaps I can fight them and drive them away.'
verses.comment: Repetition emphasizes the exodus and threat perceived by Moab, underscoring Israel's prominence in God's redemptive plan.

verses.text: But God said to Balaam, 'You must not go with them. You must not curse the people, for they are blessed.'
verses.comment: God explicitly protects His people from curses, an assurance that blessings given by God cannot be overturned by human means.

verses.text: So Balaam got up in the morning and said to Balak's officials, 'Go back to your own land, for the LORD has refused to let me go with you.'
verses.comment: Balaam obeys God, at least initially. This demonstrates that true prophecy is subject to God's will, not human manipulation.

verses.text: The Moabite officials returned to Balak and said, 'Balaam refused to come with us.'
verses.comment: Balak's first attempt fails, emphasizing that God's directives take priority over human desires and strategies.

verses.text: Then Balak sent other officials, more numerous and more distinguished than the first.
verses.comment: This escalation showcases persistence in seeking a way around God's will, something seen in other biblical narratives (cf. Pharaoh in Exodus).

verses.text: They came to Balaam and said to him, 'This is what Balak son of Zippor says: Do not let anything keep you from coming to me.'
verses.comment: The urgency of the message reflects the desperation of Balak, who is increasingly reliant on spiritual means in matters of politics and war.

verses.text: 'I will greatly honor you and do whatever you say. Only come and curse these people for me.'
verses.comment: Balak attempts to buy Balaam's cooperation, showing human attempts to manipulate divine power for personal gain.

verses.text: But Balaam answered Balak's officials, 'Even if Balak gave me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond what the LORD my God commands.'
verses.comment: Balaam professes obedience to the LORD over personal gain, a significant theme that connects to the call to self-sacrifice in the New Testament.

verses.text: 'Now please stay here tonight, so that I may find out what else the LORD will say to me.'
verses.comment: Balaam continues to seek God's word, indicating ongoing discernment and ultimately highlighting the principle of seeking God's will above all.

verses.text: That night God came to Balaam and said, 'If the men have come to summon you, get up and go with them, but do only what I tell you.'
verses.comment: God permits Balaam's journey, establishing the condition of obedience. God's will stands above King Balak's requests.

verses.text: So Balaam got up in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the officials of Moab.
verses.comment: The journey with the Moabite officials sets up the encounter with God's angel, emphasizing the tension between obedience and temptation.

verses.text: But God was angry because he went, and the angel of the LORD stood in the road to oppose him. Balaam was riding his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
verses.comment: God's anger and the angel's appearance highlight God's sovereignty and the role of angelic messengers as instruments of divine will.

verses.text: The donkey saw the angel of the LORD standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand. The donkey left the road and went into a field. Balaam struck the donkey to get it back on the road.
verses.comment: Animals recognizing spiritual realities is a rare motif. The donkey's perception contrasts with Balaam's blindness to God's warning.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD stood in a narrow path between the vineyards, with walls on both sides.
verses.comment: The narrowing path suggests Balaam’s diminishing options, symbolizing the struggle between God's way and human purposes.

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the LORD again, it pressed close to the wall, crushing Balaam’s foot against it. So he struck the donkey again.
verses.comment: The repeated striking reveals Balaam's lack of spiritual sensitivity. Spiritual blindness leads to frustration and mistreatment.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD moved further ahead and stood in a narrow place where there was no room to turn, either to the right or the left.
verses.comment: God closes off every alternative, underlining the importance of obedience and the futility of resisting the divine will.

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, it lay down under Balaam. Balaam was furious and struck the donkey with his staff.
verses.comment: The donkey’s submission starkly contrasts with Balaam’s anger, symbolizing humility versus pride—a spiritual lesson echoed in Christ’s teachings (Luke 14:11).

verses.text: Then the LORD opened the donkey’s mouth, and it said to Balaam, 'What have I done to you, that you have struck me these three times?'
verses.comment: Here the narrative shows God’s power to speak through even animals, emphasizing that genuine prophecy comes unexpectedly and often from humble sources.

verses.text: Balaam answered the donkey, 'You have made a fool of me! If only I had a sword in my hand, I would kill you right now.'
verses.comment: Balaam’s angry reply shows pride and frustration, while the fact that he responds at all reveals the miraculous nature of the event.

verses.text: The donkey said to Balaam, 'Am I not your own donkey, which you have always ridden, to this day? Have I ever been in the habit of doing this to you?' 'No,' Balaam replied.
verses.comment: The donkey’s rational defense further highlights Balaam’s blindness. It calls into question whether miraculous revelation may come in unexpected forms.

verses.text: Then the LORD opened Balaam's eyes, and he saw the angel of the LORD standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand. So Balaam bowed low and fell facedown.
verses.comment: Vision of the angel causes Balaam to humble himself. Bowing down is an act of worship and surrender, crucial in understanding God’s authority.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD asked him, 'Why have you struck your donkey these three times? I've come here to oppose you, because your path is recklessly against me.'
verses.comment: The angel corrects Balaam’s course, showing that spiritual discernment requires true openness to God’s correction, not just ritual or tradition.

verses.text: The donkey saw me and turned away these three times. If it had not turned away, I would have certainly killed you by now, but spared the donkey.
verses.comment: The donkey’s actions preserved Balaam’s life, exemplifying God’s mercy and protection even in the midst of our errors.

verses.text: Balaam said to the angel of the LORD, 'I have sinned. I did not realize you were standing in the road to oppose me. If my going is displeasing to you, I will turn back.'
verses.comment: Balaam confesses his sin. The importance of recognizing and admitting fault stands out as a key step in reconciliation with God—a pattern continued in Christian sacramental practice.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD said to Balaam, 'Go with these men, but speak only what I tell you.' So Balaam went with Balak’s officials.
verses.comment: Divine restriction on what Balaam can say shows true prophecy is under God’s authority, prefiguring apostolic submission (cf. John 14:10).

verses.text: When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him at the city of Moab, on the border at the edge of his territory.
verses.comment: Balak’s eagerness to welcome Balaam reveals his hope for control through spiritual power, a recurring but often mistaken motif.

verses.text: Balak said to Balaam, 'Didn’t I send messengers to summon you? Why didn't you come right away? Don’t you think I can honor you?'
verses.comment: Balak’s focus on honor reflects worldly priorities, while Balaam’s response will highlight the supremacy of God’s word.

verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, 'Look, I have come to you now, but I can't say just anything. I must speak only what God puts in my mouth.'
verses.comment: The limitation of Balaam’s speech by God foreshadows principles in apostolic preaching and authority, emphasizing obedience in ministry.

verses.text: Then Balaam went with Balak to Kiriath-huzoth.
verses.comment: Kiriath-huzoth's mention situates the encounter in a specific place, recalling biblical geography often linked to spiritual significance.

verses.text: Balak offered cattle and sheep, and he gave some to Balaam and the princes with him.
verses.comment: Sacrificial offerings were customary to seek divine favor. In Christian interpretation, foreshadows the sacrificial system fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: The next morning Balak took Balaam and brought him up to Bamoth Baal, from where he could see the edge of the Israelite camp.
verses.comment: Bamoth Baal, a high place, highlights locations for spiritual encounters. Viewing the camp reflects prophetic vision, a theme picked up in New Testament prophecy and apostolic witness.
